The "527 Fairness Act of 2005" repeals the aggregate limit on contributions by individuals. The "527 Fairness Act of 2005" repeals the limit on contributions by individuals under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Amendments are made to increase limits for Senate candidates facing wealthy opponents. The "527 Fairness Act of 2005" repeals contribution limits for individuals under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 and increases limits for Senate candidates facing wealthy opponents. The "527 Fairness Act of 2005" repeals contribution limits for individuals under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 and increases limits for Senate candidates facing wealthy opponents. Additionally, it repeals the limit on the amount of party expenditures on behalf of candidates in general elections. The "527 Fairness Act of 2005" repeals contribution limits for individuals under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 and removes restrictions on the amounts of expenditures for federal office. It also eliminates paragraphs (2), (3), and (4) of Section 315(d) and makes conforming amendments to Section 315(c) of the Act. The "527 Fairness Act of 2005" removes contribution limits for individuals under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 and eliminates restrictions on federal office expenditures. It also makes amendments to Section 315(i) of the Act, increasing limits for senate candidates facing wealthy opponents. The "527 Fairness Act of 2005" removes contribution limits for individuals under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 and eliminates restrictions on federal office expenditures. It also amends Section 315A(a) of the Act, increasing limits for house candidates facing wealthy opponents. The "527 Fairness Act of 2005" removes contribution limits for individuals and eliminates restrictions on federal office expenditures. It also amends Section 315A(a) of the Act, increasing limits for house candidates facing wealthy opponents. Additionally, party expenditures previously made are addressed by striking certain provisions. SEC. 4 increases contribution limits for political committees, with amendments to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Contributions are raised from $5,000 to $7,500. SEC. 5 introduces indexing of all contribution limits. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase limitations on contributions for political committees in calendar years after 2002 and 2006. Amounts are adjusted and rounded to the nearest multiple of $100. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase limitations on contributions for political committees in calendar years after 2002 and 2006. Amounts are adjusted and rounded to the nearest multiple of $100. Amendments include adjustments to specific sections and the determination of the base year. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase limitations on contributions for political committees in calendar years after 2002 and 2006, with adjustments made to specific sections and the determination of the base year. Additionally, a new clause is added for purposes of subsections (a)(1)(C), (a)(1)(D), and (a)(2) for calendar year 2005. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to allow transfers between leadership committees of individuals holding Federal office and national party committees without limitations on contributions. SEC. 7 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to increase the threshold for contributions and expenditures required for political committee treatment to $10,000. SEC. 8 prohibits contributions to Section 527 organizations by foreign nationals. SEC. 9 requires Section 527 organizations to submit reports under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Section 304(a) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require organizations described in section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code to submit reports in the same manner as political committees. This does not apply to certain organizations as specified. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to allow organizations to make expenditures for targeted electioneering communications. The types of organizations eligible to make expenditures are expanded to include section 501(c)(5) and (6) organizations. Definitions are updated to reflect these changes. The Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to clarify the tax treatment of expenditures made by section 501(c)(4), (5), or (6) organizations. SEC. 11 expands the ability of corporations and labor organizations to communicate with members by allowing communications to be addressed or delivered. SEC. 12 permits state and local political parties to use nonfederal funds for voter registration and sample ballots. The amendment to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 expands voter registration activities and allows for the preparation of sample ballots for elections involving candidates for Federal office. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include provisions for candidates for State or local office on the ballot. Amendments are made to sections regarding voter registration activities and sample ballot preparation for Federal office candidates. SEC. 13 clarifies the authorization of federal candidates and officeholders to attend fundraising events for state or local political parties. SEC. 14 modifies the definition of public communication to exclude communications over the Internet. SEC. 15 addresses candidate communications containing endorsements by federal candidates or officeholders. The amendment to the Federal Election Campaign Act clarifies that a disbursement for an electioneering communication referring to a candidate for Federal office is not considered coordinated solely because it contains a State or local endorsement. The term 'State or local endorsement' includes endorsements by the candidate for State or local office or another candidate for Federal office. The amendment clarifies that a disbursement for an electioneering communication referring to a candidate for Federal office is not considered coordinated solely because it contains a State or local endorsement. This includes endorsements by the candidate for State or local office or another candidate for Federal office. The effective date for these amendments is for elections occurring on or after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 16. SEVERABILITY.

If any provision of this Act or any amendment made by this Act is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act and its amendments will not be affected.

SEC. 17. EFFECTIVE DATE.

The amendments made by this Act will be effective from January 1, 2006.
